snippet.textDisplay:
The problem is that in prior years, when social media hate mobs weren't such a problem, the damage these crazies could do if they melted down was far more limited. Obviously you don't want a toxic person on your set, but in the case of Ray Fisher, he showed how crazy/angry people could make things even more expensive for these companies.

Because these Hollywood actors are likely to have big follower counts on Twitter, it is very easy for them to whip up a social justice mob at the drop of a hat with the vaguest allegations of "abuse." So, thanks to Fisher, Hollywood film companies now have to concern themselves over social media PR nightmares. As a consequence, you will see directors take less chances with people like Robert Downey Jr. in the future. The costs of these melting down are simply becoming too high to tolerate.

My guess is Amber Heard is never going to be involved in a major motion picture production again. Anyone else who doesn't have a good reputation or credentials can expect similar treatment.
